title: Introduction
body: Collaborative Working eLearning

title: Understanding Collaboration, its benefits and challenges
displayTitle: Understanding Collaboration, its benefits and challenges
body:
The term collaboration comes from Latin, collaborare which means “to work with”.

This learning will introduce you to the benefits and challenges of working with different departments, organisations and individuals. Watch the video to find out more.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Collaboration in the workplace is essential for a successful career, whether you are working with different organisations or asking someone from a different team for support and guidance.

Successful collaboration can lead to the achievement of goals and joint objectives, cohesion between teams, and create a diverse and knowledgeable working group.

But what is collaborative working, and why is it important?

The Institute for Collaborative Working describes collaboration as:

“People working jointly on an activity or project to achieve a common goal. Especially where this involves co-operation between several teams, departments and/or different organisations to achieve an agreed objective.”

For successful collaboration we need to develop working environments and demonstrate behaviours which enable us and others to perform at their best.

We need to be attentive of the wider working group and make sure we are all working towards a single purpose.

We need to ensure that we involve the right individuals at the right time and, regular negotiations should be in place to help the group reach mutual agreements.

Collaborative working does not always mean working in a team, we still need to make decisions, keep on top of our own tasks and ensure things happen. However, we also need to keep our minds open and proactively engage in collaboration.

Sometimes collaboration is perceived as a burden and difficult especially when trying to merge organisations and cultures.

Collaborative working does have its challenges such as:
  • Communication
  • Leadership Support
  • Traditional ways of working
  • Parochial attitudes
  • Approach to risk
  • Motivational and incentivisation
  • Knowledge, skills and abilities
  • Creating a collaborative culture
  • How to start, when to end
  • Extending trust
  • Articulating and evaluating success

If everyone strives for collaborative working then the benefits can far outweigh the challenges.

Effective collaboration happens when the stakeholders of a project or team can bring together structures, processes and skills to achieve integration to benefit, strategic, tactical, operational, interpersonal and cultural working practices.

But what does this mean for you and your organisation?

Working in this way allows for knowledge sharing and helps to create a culture of continuous improvement.

Duplication is reduced which results in better use of resources.

Collaboration can allow us to work in new ways, allowing for creativity and innovation to achieve our outcomes.

Collaborative working increases trust, satisfaction and performance both for individuals and the organisation as a whole.

title: Collaborative approaches and reactions
body: Collaborative working eLearning

title: Introduction
body:
This module will focus on:
  • Why people struggle with collaborative working
  • The values and behavioural standards expected by your organisation
  • The pro-social aspects of collaborative behaviour
  • The benefits of an emotionally intelligent approach to collaboration
  • Recognising our reactions and behaviours in collaborative situations

title: Collaborative approaches and reactions
body:
We have explored what collaborative behaviour is and its benefits to individuals and organisations. If there are such impactful benefits then why do people (and organisations) struggle with collaboration and how can we approach it for success?

Watch the animation to find out more.

Play the video to see...

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Have you ever felt apprehensive at the beginning of a project, when you meet new team members?

You may have felt defensive? Not quite ready to trust others and need to size them up before you contribute any ideas?

Although these feelings and behaviours may occur, successful collaboration means we must start by being curious, explore options and extend trust so we can contribute and join in.

Sam is the project lead for a temporary team.

The team is formed from across three organisations and has been brought together for six months to design and deploy a recruitment drive to employ 10 new external social media experts.

The team brings together

Fatimah who was recruited a year ago having successfully completed her MSc in Social Media.

Josh a recruitment specialist and a member of the HR department.

Clare a specialist in analysing big data.

Phil skilled in advertising and stakeholder relationships.

Francois is a representative from the finance, resources and facilities department.

The team will be located in accommodation belonging to one of the organisations in the middle of Manchester.

For the time being however, they are working virtually from home, but will be expected to attend the office from time to time when necessary.

Sam is preparing for her first meeting with the new team, she wants the team to engage fully, come with an open mind and be accepting of each other.

Sam is reviewing an image from a recent article about conscious behaviours for inclusion.

She writes down some key words, to use in the kick off meeting as she plans a discussion on ways of working.

She will ask everyone to contribute and share their ideas about how they can use these behaviours to support their collaborative working.

title: Standards and values
body:
Each organisation has its own values and behavioural standards which makes it unique and able to fulfil its individual responsibilities.

Collaborative working is a theme in each organisation’s values.

The infographic highlights sections of each organisation's standards and values where collaboration is intertwined.

More information regarding organisation values can be found on the Academy’s ‘Personal and organisational values’ learning.

Select each image to find out more on...

_items.title: North - Collective commitment
_items.body:
We depend on our collective and individual commitment to teamwork:
  • Teamwork - Working as one organisation, bringing together in common purpose the best that everyone can give, supporting colleagues and treating each other with respect, and forging close partnerships and teams with others we depend upon.

_items.title: South - Deep partnerships and cultural expertise
_items.body:
We have deep partnerships and cultural expertise.

We value the contribution of every individual but we work as a team.

  • Respect - We act with humanity and respect. We are a community. We esteem partnership.

_items.title: West - Ingenuity and teamwork
_items.body:
• Ingenuity - We make best use of people, technology and tradecraft.
  • Teamwork - We value each other’s unique and diverse contributions. We reach across boundaries. We have an inclusive community spirit. We trust, support and care for each other. We inspire each other to be the best we can be.

title: Collaborative behaviours
body:
Pro-social behaviour is positive, helpful, and intended to promote social acceptance and friendship.

It includes activities such as helping, sharing, donating, co-operating and volunteering.

It has significant impact for developing desirable collaborative traits and enhances task performance.

title: Katz and Miller
body: In this section we look at the conscious actions and behaviours we can take to develop an inclusive environment which can facilitate successful collaborations.

title: Outcomes
body:
Outcomes

Judith Katz and Frederick Miller from the Kaleel Jamison Consulting Group, published a ten page article which summarises the behaviours to focus on to create inclusive, collaborative cultures.

They recommend four keys to success and eight sustaining behaviours which when adopted successfully, can result in people feeling more valued, supported, energized and engaged.

Evidence shows when organisations have implemented this approach, information flows faster amongst the team and organisations and people are more willing to speak up, make problems visible, and resolve misunderstandings or disagreements. This in turn leads to collaboration happening more quickly and Individuals and teams making and implementing decisions more effectively as silos break down and productivity soars.

title: Four keys to collaboration
body:
Review the four keys to collaboration and the related sustaining behaviours and consider how often you see these demonstrated in the workplace.

Select the icons on the image to find out more.
_feedback:
Lean into discomfort

Trusting others is fundamental for productive collaborations, having trust in other people and teams takes time to develop. An environment where we can make ourselves vulnerable and extend that to others will allow team members to raise issues and contribute.

Tips
  • Use language to signal you are moving out of your comfort zone
  • Take small steps, speak when you would normally be silent or sit at the front when you would usually sit at the back
  • Discuss what you need to help you feel able to speak up and encourage others to do the same

Listen as an ally

When we listen as an ally, we need to listen actively and with full attention, viewing the other person as partners not opponents.

Tips
  • Give your full attention, do not multitask
  • Restate what you have heard to make sure you have understood the intended message
  • Accept what others say is true for them, it may be different from your thinking but it is still valid
  • Give back the same energy and express appreciation for what is shared

State intent and intensity

When we clearly state what we mean (intent) and how committed we are to an idea (intensity), it allows others to act appropriately, quickly and decisively with no time wasted on second guessing.

Tips
  • Let others know that you are still interested in their opinions
  • Seek feedback from team members on your use of levels of intent and intensity

Share your street corner

Collaboration allows an organisation to bring together different perspectives, making sure all perspectives are covered, leading to more effective solutions and decision making.

Tips
  • Make others feel safe in contributing
  • Treat others as experts in their own experience
  • Build on what another person has shared to find a new solution together

title: Sustaining behaviours
body:
To facilitate partnerships, collaboration and teamwork use the eight sustaining behaviours in addition to the four keys.

Select the icons on the image to find out more.

_items.body:
Greet people authentically

Say “hello” — “A simple, authentic “hello” to acknowledge others, whether in a team meeting or just walking down the hallway, is a key step toward ensuring that people feel seen and included.”

Create a sense of safety for yourself and your team members

If a team wants to achieve high performance, raise difficult issues, identify and solve problems, and make decisions rapidly, everyone must feel safe enough to speak up, share their thinking, voice their opinions, take risks, partner with others, and join as full participants.”

Work for the common good and shared success

“Establishing, verifying, and constantly updating a shared understanding of the organisation’s common goals can help overcome divides and silos that plague so many organisations.”

Ensure right people, right work, right time

Ask who else needs to be involved in order to understand the whole situation — “Even the most insightful and productive meeting can be limited if those who have important perspectives related to a project, problem, or decision are not present. Sometimes, one key person’s absence can leave an ever-so-important street corner/ perspective out of the conversation — leading to rework, delays, waste, and even failure.”

Link to others’ ideas, thoughts and feelings — give energy back

“Connection is about connecting and letting people know they have been heard. It is a way to give “energy back” and to let people know the impact of their ideas, thoughts, and feelings on others.”

Speak up when people are being made “small” or excluded

“The assumption that people will speak up if they have something to say is often incorrect. If we want to encourage new ideas and ensure the richest and best thinking, it is incumbent on all members of the team to be allies, to make room for all voices to be heard, and to be responsible for the team’s efforts and results.”

Address misunderstandings and resolve disagreements

Work “pinches” — “The challenge is to address, not avoid, misunderstandings; to explore and address disagreements and differences, not ignore or suppress them. When disagreements or misunderstandings go unaddressed — as people continue to avoid the issue — it creates waste. Talk to others about their concerns and work around team members with whom are misunderstood or have a “pinch”.

Build trust

Do what you say you will do, and honour confidentiality — “When people feel that sense of trust, they are willing to give each other the benefit of the doubt — and in turn, speed up the level of interaction, problem solving, and decision making. This dynamic, however, only takes place when people can count on one another to do what they say they will do, when everyone knows that each individual will live by her or his commitments and honour confidential statements.”

title: Four keys in action
body:
We have explored the approaches and behaviours which can support collaboration but how can you put it into action?

Watch the animation to find out more.

Play the video to see...

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Collaborative working means we have to trust others with our work. Often that work is important to us and this reliance on others may lead to 'people feeling less in control and unsure about the outcome.

Without the right skills, working collaboratively is challenging, particularly when people have different thinking and learning styles.

In order to work collaboratively the new team Sam is leading will need to communicate effectively to achieve the project goal, which Sam knows is even more important when working virtually.

As the team discuss their ways of working, a conversation about taking notes in meetings comes up, Josh explains that he finds it difficult normally to do this but responds by offering to try it out.

By Josh stepping out of his comfort zone and leaning into the discomfort, it helps to build trust within the team.

The team are listening to Phil’s ideas about external parties who can assist with recruitment. They begin to build on what he has said and reflect on methods that will accommodate the time and geographical constraints.

By paying attention and listening deeply they are demonstrating their shared conviction of all being in it together.

Sam reminds everyone that the first project milestone is approaching.

Josh explains how media and advertising agencies will likely return quick results and states he will collate a list and share with the group in the next few days.

When we clearly state what we mean and how committed we are it enables others to act quickly, decisively, and correctly.

Towards the end of the meeting Sam asks everyone to share an update on project progress in their areas and also flag other work commitments or competing priorities.

Fatimah explains she has IT issues so is working from the office and not available for early team calls due to traveling.

Francoise shares he has capacity issues due to end of year finances so he may be slower at responding.

Sam thanks everyone for sharing and asks that they all keep these issues in mind.

Now the team have a comprehensive understanding of each other’s situation this can allow for better decisions to be made.

title: Reflection point
body:
Which of the key behaviours feels more natural to you?
  • Pick one key behaviour, which you could start with, focus on it, master it and then move on to the next one.
  • Think about how often you use the sustaining behaviours, try one day where you focus on using these more to see what difference it makes.

You may find it helpful to print or save this image for future reference. Either print the page from your browser or take a screen shot.

title: Emotional intelligence
body:
Daniel Goleman, author of Emotional Intelligence (1996) adapted Salovey and Mayer’s emotional intelligence model (1990) to develop five emotional and social competencies: self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy and social skills.

Select the icons on the image to find out more.
_feedback:
Self-awareness

The ability to understand and interpret one’s own feelings through internal reflection. Self-awareness is important in nurturing good relationships with colleagues and in the creation of positive and productive teamwork skills. Team members need to be aware of the potential impact of their unregulated emotions and their potential detriment to the broader team. Team members with emotional intelligence demonstrate confidence, originating from their own emotional self-awareness and self-regulation.

Self-Regulation

Being more aware of emotions allows for self-regulation which in turn has a number of benefits enabling one to:
  • Use appropriate emotions to facilitate the progress of a work activity
  • Foresee, prevent or manage conflict
  • Recognise pressure and stress and to build resilience
  • Promote positive, effective and efficient working relationships with other team members
  • Allow the task to be placed first rather than emotions, thereby ensuring task completion

Motivation

Being able to motivate oneself is a very effective, emotionally intelligent characteristic. The ability to elicit discretionary effort in others through increased motivation is also a valuable tool in pursuance of task achievement. In order to feel motivated, team members need to feel valued, confident that they are led well and are enthusiastic about the mission. Motivation is a shared responsibility between the individual, team members and leaders.

Empathy

Empathy is understanding and interpreting colleagues’ feelings and being able to identify with their feelings by understanding their perspective and cultivating rapport with people from different ‘walks of life’. Empathic team members embrace difference and understand the role of diversity in nurturing productive human relationships and enhancing the team effectiveness through the multiplicity of thinking styles.

Social Skills

Team members have a shared responsibility to encourage cooperation, collaboration and teamwork through the skills of human interactivity such as rapport building dialogue, positive body language, empathic questioning and active listening. These skills allow for positive and trusting relationships which have the capacity to manage tensions via discussions, rather than arguments and focus team members around task achievement.

title: Self-reflection & awareness
body:
Self-reflection helps to build emotional intelligence and especially self-awareness. By taking the time to ask yourself some important questions, you gain a better understanding of your emotions, strengths, challenges and motivations.

Self-reflection allows us to examine experiences that go well and not so well. It allows us to learn from these successes and challenges. There are many models to guide our thinking and achieve an appropriate mindset for an appreciative and critical inquiry of ourselves.

title: Gibbs’ Reflective Cycle
body: Gibbs' Reflective Cycle was developed by Graham Gibbs in 1988 to give structure to learning from experiences. It offers a framework for examining experiences, and given its cyclic nature lends itself particularly well to repeated experiences, allowing you to learn and plan from things that either went well or didn’t go well.

title: Applying the cycle
instruction: Select the title to see more information on...

_items.title: Stages
_items.body:
Gibbs Reflective Cycle covers six stages:
  • Description of the experience
  • Feelings and thoughts about the experience
  • Evaluation of the experience, both good and bad
  • Analysis to make sense of the situation
  • Conclusion about what you learned and what you could have done differently
  • Action plan for how you would deal with similar situations in the future, or general changes you might find appropriate

_items.title: Experience
_items.body: This model provides a good way to work through an experience. This can be either a stand-alone experience or a situation you go through frequently, for example, meetings with a team you have to collaborate with. Gibbs originally advocated its use in repeated situations, but the stages and principles apply equally well for single experiences too. If done with a stand-alone experience, the action plan may become more general and look at how you can apply your conclusions in the future.

_items.title: Checklist
_items.body:
Self-Reflection Checklist
The purpose of this checklist is to facilitate you in your initial self-reflection, here are some areas for you to think about:
  • Space: The correct environment which allows for focus
  • Mindset: The right mindset for focus and attention clear of strong invasive emotion which may hinder broad reflection
  • Time: Reserving sufficient and regular time
  • Process: Choose a thinking model to structure your reflection
  • Document: Recording your thoughts over time creates a greater self-awareness of your thought processes and commitments
  • Share: With greater sharing of the outcomes comes greater commitment to the outcome

_items.title: Reflection
_items.body:
Reflect on what you have learnt and answer the following questions this, can be either in your head or written in a journal:

Think of a recent situation where you experienced strong emotion (at work)
  • What was the emotion?
  • What triggered it?
  • What emotional need was not being fulfilled?
  • How did you handle that emotion and how did that impact the outcome?
    • If you handled it well - what learning can you apply to other situations?
    • If you did not handle it well - what can you do differently next time?

title: Reactions
body:
When collaborating, be aware of the emotions and reactions we can experience from ourselves to others and from others towards the situation.

This may not always be easily visible or vocalised, and so looking out for signs and signals can help you to recognise key reactions and related behaviours.

Select the title to see more information on…

_items.body:
It’s human to experience different reactions and emotions to new or challenging collaborative work arrangements.

Watch out for these reactions in yourself and others: apathetic or competitive, anger, agreement, engagement, dismissiveness, narrow-mindedness.

Stress and anxiety can also result when working in difficult collaborative situations and can manifest in a number of ways. Watch out for the below reactions in yourself and others:
  • Behavioural factors will be demonstrated by what we say or do such as taking more work home, being accident prone, becoming withdrawn and not caring.
  • Physical reactions can be seen in how the body responds. Tiredness, nausea, headaches, weight loss or weight gain are common symptoms which you may observe.
  • Psychological reactions happen in the mind and usually deal with our emotions, thought processes and the way the brain works. Signs often shown are short tempers, moodiness, negativity, anger or being over sensitive.

Recognising reactions can help you to reflect and be mindful of your own and others when working collaboratively.

You can take steps to manage your reactions and emotions by:
  • Identifying emotions and observed reactions in yourself and others and use the four keys of collaboration for support.
  • Exploring the basis of the emotion in yourself where is it coming from (ego, own agenda, different priorities/ impact on personal values).
  • Using Gibbs reflective cycle to help you explore and observe a situation impartially.

Resilience is taken from the Latin word resilio, which means the ability to “jump back”. In modern terms having resilience is to have the ability to bounce back from adversity and stress which you may experience during collaborative working.

We can all develop resilience and look after our own wellbeing by taking the following steps:
  • Make some lifestyle changes and create balance in your life – making time for friends, family and hobbies.
  • Look after your physical health – get enough sleep, be active and eat healthily.
  • Give yourself a break –and get a change of scenery and forgive yourself if you make a mistake!
  • Build your Support Network – speak to family and friends, HR and talk to people in similar situations.

title: Judging and joining
body:
Our behaviours and reactions can influence the situation positively or negatively when we are collaborating.

It’s important to keep in mind the behaviours which either support or sabotage.

The judging and joining behaviours are a good reference to keep in mind when joining a new collaborative working group.

title: Stating intent and intensity
body:
When in collaborative situations, discussions open on projects tasks, timelines and activities. As new ideas and new relationships are explored it can be useful to recognise the level of intent and intensity.

Katz and Miller created a guide for recognising intent and intensity, which can be useful when encouraging team members to explore different perspectives.

title: Reflection point
body:
Think about the collaborative situations you have worked in. Did you ever notice any of the following reactions and behaviours?

  • Disagreement and unhealthy debate
  • Public agreement and privately carrying on with unhelpful behaviours
  • Disengagement and apathy
  • Competitiveness

How did they play out? How could they impact the collaboration? What difference could be made if stakes and notions were used instead of boulders and tombstones?

_items.body:
At the first progress meeting Sam welcomes everyone and asks for first high-level thoughts and ideas on how to achieve the project goals?

Select the arrow to view more.

Josh is a passionate advocate for the use of the latest technology and insists that everybody should be using the latest app and workflow board to ensure full visibility of the project progress. Josh states that this is the only way forward and he can’t work in the team unless they adopt it.

Phil dismisses the app and says “Let’s just keep our focus on the task at hand and monitor progress in a project plan as usual. The focus should be on how outcome of getting the ten new external social media experts employed asap and nothing else.”
Clare suggest they all dedicate a specific time to explore the app technology further, whilst in the meantime focus on splitting up the immediate short-term tasks based on skills and experience.

body:
Which suggestion would enable the team to work effectively and reach the project goal?

Select the correct answer, then select Submit.

_items.text: Josh’s suggestion to monitor project progress through the use of the project app.
_items.feedback: Josh has presented a Tombstone which are about core values or beliefs and which leave no room for negotiation. It indicates a total commitment to the idea or issue but can result in some strong counter-views.

_items.text: Phil and his suggestion to get started with a standard project plan.
_items.feedback: Phil is only be concerned with his own opinion showing no interest for Josh’s suggestion as he completely dismisses it. By just carrying on with his own ideas regardless, he is ignoring an opportunity to develop the relationship and explore ideas.

_items.text: Clare with her approach to explore the technology and allocate short-term priorities.

_feedback.correct: Clare has provided a “Stake” like tent stakes, she has established a firm place for a discussion to start, but that place can be moved. The Stake concept is grounded in the belief that none of us is as smart as all of us. This is an important concept for effective collaborative working.

_items.body:
As the project has progressed the pressure has picked up and the team are all feeling the impact of balancing the project and their own workloads.

Select the arrow to view more.

Over the last two weeks some long hours and weekend working have been required. The contribution to the task by the team has been commendable but the pressure is starting to affect some of the team and they are reacting in different ways.

Some are visibly irritable whilst others have become withdrawn. There is an increase in negativity to the project demands and in the latest progress meetings, there was a heated debate where tempers were raised and Fatimah left the meeting abruptly.

body:
What actions could the team members each take to work through this difficult period?

Select all options that apply.

_items.text: By each listening and sharing their street corners
By offering to take on more work
By analysing and delegating each work task
By criticising the leadership of the team

_feedback.correct:
That’s right. Remaining positive and upbeat demonstrates a positive attitude can be uplifting for others, as emotions are contagious.

Listening to each other and sharing their street corners will help to surface issues and find shared solutions.

Using self-reflection tools such as Gibbs reflective cycle or checklist will help to observe the situation impartially.

Looking after wellbeing in times of pressure will build your ability to cope.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite. Remaining positive and upbeat demonstrates a positive attitude can be uplifting for others, as emotions are contagious.

Listening to each other and sharing their street corners will help to surface issues and find shared solutions.

Using self-reflection tools such as Gibbs reflective cycle or checklist will help to observe the situation impartially.

Looking after wellbeing in times of pressure will build your ability to cope.

title: Summary & next steps
body:
In this module we have looked at the keys to collaboration, emotional intelligence and self-awareness. Being able to recognise emotions and reactions in ourselves and others can help us to collaborate in a positive way. In your journal or development notebook plan how you can take forward some of the actions from this module.

Select the arrow to see more information on…

_items.title: Keys to collaboration
_items.body:
We explored the four keys to collaboration and the eight sustaining behaviours. Plan a situation where you can practice using the tips.

Think of a situation where you can practice using the four keys. Which seem natural to you? Which are you less comfortable with? Who do you know that role models these behaviours? What can you learn from them?

_items.title: Self-reflection and awareness
_items.body:
There is an onus on all of us to be self-aware, recognise our reactions and behaviours and collaborate in a positive way.

How self-aware are you? What recent situation could you use Gibbs reflective cycle to analyse what went well or not so well?

_items.title: Further resources
_items.body:
There are further resources that can help you.

The Academy learning on top tips for emotional intelligence.

Module three in this package has further practical tools to use in collaboration.

title: Mindset, dialogue and skills eLearning
displayTitle: Mindset, inner dialogue and skills for collaboration
body: Mindset, dialogue and skills eLearning

title: Introduction
body:
This module will focus on:
  • How our mindset supports or sabotages collaboration
  • The impact our inner dialogue can have
  • Different skills which support collaboration such as curiosity, communication, inclusivity and the ability of ‘learning to let go’

title: Mindset & behaviours
body:
Recognising our own mindset is important when working with others. There is a big difference between helpful and hindering mindsets when building collaborative relationships.

Being aware of our own mindset and recognising how it affects our behaviour is key, as this can influence others and create either positive or negative cycles of behaviour.

Play the video to see...

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Have you ever noticed the impact a negative or fixed mindset can have in a collaborative working group?

We can all pick up negative communication and behaviours, so it’s important to recognise our own thoughts and mindset when working in collaborative situations.

Our mindsets can dictate our thought process and outlook and in turn impact on our outcomes and results.

That combined with how we talk to ourselves through our inner dialogue can have a powerful effect on life and work in either a positive or negative way.

Meet Ted, he has been working in the organisation for some time and is used to his standard ways of working.

Ted is informed of a new training programme and as he is in a negative state of mind and does not respond well to the news.

His initial mindset is fixed and his reaction is negative and dismissive.

This mindset goes on to dictate Ted’s thinking and outcomes. As a result, he does not pick up new skills effectively, finds tasks more difficult down the line and the result is he then misses out on being part of new projects and promotions.

On a different day when Ted is thinking with a more positive and growth focussed mindset he is open to opportunity and embraces the challenge.

Ted’s growth mindset enables him to develop skills, which opens opportunities for future new projects, a different job role and a promotion.

Through his achievements and successes, he can then apply a similar approach to other situations in his life where his mindset was previously fixed – to enable him to now achieve other positive outcomes.

Our mindset and outlooks can be contagious; they can affect our thought patterns and seep into how we approach everyday tasks and behaviours in a range of situations.

Recognising and managing our mindset and inner dialogue in collaborative situations can have a transformational and positive effect if we stay open, curious and keep a growth mindset.

title: Mindsets
body:
Dr. Carol Dweck in her seminal book “Mindset” explores the concepts of a ‘growth mindset’ and a ‘fixed mindset'.

A growth mindset is a set of principles and values that suggests that one’s intelligence can be grown or developed with persistence, effort and a focus on learning.

Conversely a fixed mindset is a set of principles and values that proposes that a person has a predetermined amount of intelligence, skills or talents.

Reflection activity: Review the graphic and reflect on a time when you’ve had a fixed mindset towards something–then consider how adopting a growth mindset might have helped you achieve a different outcome.

Select the icons on the image to find out more.
_feedback:
Challenges

Fixed: Avoids challenges
Growth: Embraces challenges

Obstacles

Fixed: Gives up easily
Growth: Persists in the face of set backs

Effort

Fixed: See efforts as fruitless
Growth: Sees efforts as the path to mastery

Criticism

Fixed: Ignores useful negative feedback
Growth: Learns from criticism

Success of others

Fixed: Feels threatened by the success of others
Growth: Finds lessons and inspiration in the success of others

Results

Fixed: They may plateau early and not reach their full potential.
Growth: They reach ever higher levels of achievement.

Results

Fixed: They may plateau early and not reach their full potential.
Growth: They reach ever higher levels of achievement.

title: Reflection point
body:
Reflect on your own mindset.

  • When do you have a more fixed or more growth mindset?
  • How does it help you achieve your aims?
  • Are there specific situations where your thinking is fixed?
  • Can you recall situations where your inner dialogue is dragging you down?
  • Plan a situation where you could practice using a positive / growth mindset focused inner voice to enable a more positive outcome.
  • What would be the benefit of doing this?
  • In the context of collaboration – how might this approach bring you more positive results?

Take one of these and think it through. Experiment with it or talk to your manager or a trusted colleague about it.

Use it when collaborating with others and see what happens. Ask for feedback and incorporate this into future collaborative working opportunities to see the difference it makes.

title: Inner dialogue
body:
Recognising and acknowledging our inner dialogue can help us to shift our approach, which can result in a more positive outcome. To achieve this we need to learn to see things in a new way and move from a judge-and-be-judged framework to a learn-and-help-learn framework.
This takes commitment to growth and growth takes time, effort, and mutual support.

Select the arrow to view more.

_items.body:
Recognising your inner dialogue

Our inner dialogue is the voice in your head that:
  • Provides a real time commentary on what is happening
  • Asks and answers questions
  • Repeats words and thoughts
  • Makes judgements about ourselves and others
  • Can be a dialogue but also a monologue
  • Can be both positive and critical
Your inner dialogue and thinking patterns can be so entrenched that it is difficult to see or identify them, often you can be left thinking “this is me”

Positive inner dialogue

Although our inner voice assesses risk and potential harm and protects us from threatening situations, it can also be critical and linked to self-doubt, self-denial, and be present in your limiting beliefs or imposter syndrome. This can be an obstacle to problem solving, decision making, effective collaboration and goal achievement. We say things like:
  • “That is too hard”
  • “They will never help me”
  • “There is no chance that we will agree on anything”
  • “They do things in such different ways”
  • “Why would I want to work with them”
  • “I can do this better myself”
  • “I don’t know enough to be part of this group”

title: Our inner dialogue
body: Play the video to see...

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
When we go about our daily lives we enter into a range of different situations which generate different feelings and thought patterns.

Our internal dialogue can give a running commentary as events unfold, which determine how we think, react and how we behave and respond.

These thoughts can be helpful or hindering.
New collaborative situations can be daunting so it’s important to learn how you can manage your inner voice to achieve the best results.

Sometimes it may seem that others have got it all worked out, and this can often lead to a critical inner voice surfacing and holding you back.

Other people’s success, can lead to feelings of inadequacy where your critical inner voice takes over.

It’s at this point you can either let the voice overwhelm you, or you can take control of the situation.

Once you recognise the critical voice there are steps you can take to manage it.

First learn to recognise the voice, and instead of listening to the critic, turn down the negative self-talk.

Instead try to be kind and compassionate to yourself, as if you were talking to a friend.
Next make a conscious choice about your actions.

Will you step forward and join in or be overwhelmed with negative thoughts?
Remember others will also be navigating their own thoughts and inner voice, which can result in people judging others.

It can also lead to people not joining in or collaborating at all, they too could be overwhelmed or managing their own conflicting objectives.
Once you learn to recognise your inner voice you can get better at managing it and reframing your critical thought patterns.

title: Reflection point
body:
Acknowledging and listening to your inner voice is the first step in learning how to manage it. Review the following reflection activities and choose the one which you feel most comfortable with.

Reflection activity 1:
Take a piece of paper and draw your inner voice or inner critic - lead it take shape on paper. Listen and identify what it is saying then ask some questions around it:
  • How big is it?
  • Does it have an emotion or expression?
  • Does it remind you of someone you know?
  • Does it have a name?


Reflection activity 2:
Review the following points and reflect on specific situations where you could try out the following tips:
  • Become more aware of what your inner voice is saying.
  • Can you identify the trigger for the voice and where it comes from?
  • Are there situations where it always arises, does it become louder or more frequent at certain times?
  • How can you deal with it going forward in these situations?
  • Can you redirect your thoughts to what is positive in your life and what you are grateful for?
  • Try replacing often repeated self-critical and self-doubting sentences with a more positive replacement.
  • Imagine the voice coming through a radio that has volume controls on it – would it be helpful to turn down the volume?

title: Curiosity
body:
Curiosity is an essential skill and mindset which aids collaboration. Without it, much context, learning and detail will be missed.

Select the arrow to view more.

_items.body:
Curiosity

Being curious and keeping an open mind creates a willingness to explore opinions, different perspectives and reflect on the options available. The ability to develop and demonstrate curiosity is essential when working in a collaborative environment.

Perspectives

Demonstrating curiosity and being open minded allows you to see things from other perspectives – to be aware of alternative ways of doing and seeing things and to show an interest.

Going into collaborative situations seeking to find out about other people’s perspectives will enable you to stand in their shoes and understand a different point of view. Being interested in other’s agendas and ways of working can help find new solutions and common ground – particularly when problem solving or looking for innovation and creativity.

Spending time in another person’s shoes can also give you the space you need to be objective about your own behaviour. This can help you understand how your behaviour and actions are interpreted and how they impact on other people, as well as the outcomes they lead to.

Curious questions

Using curious questions can help you to become an effective communicator and open your thought processes. Curious questions are often open questions that begin with: who, what, where, when and how?

Using open questions demonstrates that the person asking the question has an intention to learn more.

Open curious questions are about the expansion of the conversation, which can help to build relationships and enable you to understand those you are collaborating with. For example:
  • What do you think of this idea?
  • How could we improve on the next deliverable?

Activity and resources

Consider for a moment your own questioning ability. How often do you hear yourself asking open questions in order to find out more about others?

When was the last time you demonstrated curiosity when working with others? What impact did this have?

How could you take action today, to develop your curiosity skills further?

There are further resources in module three which can help you develop curiosity within yourself and an activity which offers tips and techniques on using curiosity to aid collaboration.

body:
You are part of a new cross-organisational team, which has been working on allocating tasks, and defining milestones for the project plan.
Which question would you ask to open the conversation?

Select the correct answer, then select Submit.

_items.text: Can you tell us when the first milestone is due?
How should we agree milestones and accountability?
What tasks am I being allocated?

_feedback.correct: That’s right, asking how you can agree on milestones and task allocation will expand the conversation, develop a dialogue and help you learn more about those you are working with.

_incorrect.final: That’s not right, asking how you can agree on milestones and task allocation will expand the conversation, develop a dialogue and help you learn more about those you are working with.

title: Faster communication
body:
It is easy to get communication with another person wrong and we have all been misunderstood at some point. Many of us will regret having sent an email or text. Once it’s gone it’s gone and you are left to manage the consequences of your actions.

The FASTER communication method is a thinking tool. It has been designed for you to reflect, not only on individual messages you wish to send but to help you identify where you might most commonly get it wrong or how you can further professionalise your communication skills.

  • Formulate – Consider what message you want to send and to whom.
  • Anticipate – The response you may receive to what you say and how you say it.
  • Send – Send in the most appropriate format.
  • Translate- By the receiver, has it landed and has it accurately communicated what you wanted to say?
  • Evaluate – Assess the meaning of the message and construct a response.
  • Reply –Transmit via the most appropriate method.

title: Communication
body:
To be successful when we collaborate we need to communicate effectively. This is not just about what we say or messages we send.

Review the tips below to see ways in which you could improve your communication skills
instruction: Select the title to see more information on...

_items.title: Clarity
_items.body: Being clear in our communications by using techniques such as the Faster communication framework can help. However to ensure clarity it is also important to outline areas which are negotiable or non-negotiable, as well as communicating and sharing the situation from our own perspectives. Outlining our own position and encouraging others to do the same is key to gaining clarity when working collaboratively.

_items.title: Understanding
_items.body: Listening is a key skill to master and when you approach communication with the focus of “seek first to understand”, it will allow you to develop a deeper understanding and connection of the situation from the other person’s perspective.

_items.title: Personal influence
_items.body:
We all have the ability to use personal influence and this is a skill which can be developed to help us work more effectively when collaborating. Review the list below which gives some examples of how you might consider developing your own sources of influence:
  • Get involved in a learning project in your organisation to help you demonstrate your expertise and interest. This can help you to open conversations and build rapport when working collaboratively.
  • Think strategically about networking and stakeholder management - who can you connect with, are they a role model or could they help you in the future?
  • Find an opportunity with a colleague to demonstrate your questioning skills: listen well and encourage the other person to do most of the talking – this will help you to connect, be curious and understand things from their perspective.
  • Consider others, what are their motivations, how connected are you? How can you improve connections to help you collaborate – for example could you develop rapport through conversations about outside interests and activities? How might your personal influence help you to build relationships?

_items.title: Collaboration and influence
_items.body:
A key collaborative skill is to be able to influence others fairly and openly. Being able to disagree healthily, come to a compromise and to conduct a meaningful dialogue with positive intent on both sides are key characteristics of good teamwork.

Review the following points and consider within your own working environment, whether you demonstrate these behaviours or how you could experiment and develop them further?
  • Connection: How do you build relationships and connect with others or value different inputs? How can you create rapport and match the energy of others that you work with?
  • Presence: How confident are you? Are you ever over confident? How does that affect others? How do you demonstrate assertiveness and persuasiveness without becoming arrogant?
  • Competence: Are you dynamic in your thinking and communication style? How could you develop these skills?
  • Loyalty: How do you work towards and promote the benefits of working towards the greater good? How do you demonstrate commitment?

_items.title: Influencing tactics
_items.body:
Everybody uses a range of influencing tactics to suit the situation they are in. We learn and refine our influencing tactics as we grow our interpersonal and professional skills. Some of these skills sit at the sub-conscious level and we can be hardly aware that we are using them. Alternatively, we can deploy influencing tactics as an intentional strategy such as in a negotiation or conflict resolution scenario.

There are additional resources in module three which will help you to further explore and recognise your personal influencing power and influencing strategies.

title: Reflection
body:
Communication
How well do you communicate when collaborating, what’s your style of communication and what do you need to be more aware of when communicating with others? Could your influence, clarity or listening skills be improved? Make a plan to become more conscious of your communicating styles when in collaborative situations. Remember to ‘begin with the end in mind’. Think about the outcomes that you want to achieve – and the communication approach that will get you the most likely positive outcome you are looking for.

Connections, presence, competence, loyalty
What do these really mean? How are they demonstrated across organisations?
What actions can you take forward to experiment with? What will be the benefit of doing this?

title: Inclusion
body:
There are significant benefits of having diversity in the workforce and these benefits also have a positive effect on collaborative working.

When communicating it is important to be inclusive and consider the wider needs of those around you, whether that is in terms of their experience, background, preferences, communication style, skills and abilities.

You may not agree with everyone’s perspectives and you don’t need to but it’s important to value all contributions.

title: Communication styles
body:
We all have different communication styles and it’s important to be aware of your own and of those who you are working with in order to act inclusively.

The following flip cards highlight some of the traits of the most common styles. Recognising these traits can help you collaborate and be more inclusive with your communications.

_items.title: Relator
_items.body:
Priority on close relationships. Harmonizer, friendly, patient, listens, calms, affirms, empathetic and sympathetic. Stable, slow, self-controlled and conscientious worker.

Prefers to be consulted about their ideas, wants support for their feelings. Likes a personal relaxed low tension work environment.

_items.title: Initiator
_items.body:
Innovative, animated, energetic, spontaneous, fun-loving, risk taker, relies on intuition, takes action, inspires, promotes, celebrates, expressive and persuasive.

Motivated by excellence, principles, goals, causes, wants support for their ideas. Likes a stimulating, personal, friendly work environment.

_items.title: Analyser
_items.body:
Critical thinker, considers facts, data and details, organised, systematic, diplomatic, precise, thorough, and cautious.

Prefers logic, reason and no quick changes, wants support for their thoughts, and wants structure and a functional work environment.

_items.title: Director
_items.body:
Results orientated, possibilities thinker, independent, ambitious and easily bored. Driven, fast decisive, confident, competitive, takes charge and accepts responsibility, considers the bottom line.

Prefers less restrictions, opportunities and challenge. Wants support for goals, likes a busy, efficient, structured and formal work environment.

title: Reflection point
body:
Reflection activity: Which of the four communication styles most closely reflects you? Consider what this means in terms of your ability to demonstrate inclusion and to communicate effectively when working collaboratively.

  • What might you consider doing differently because of what you have learned about these different styles? What benefit will this have?
  • Where does your style support you in collaborating effectively?
  • Where might your preferred style hinder collaboration?

title: Letting go
body:
When we collaborate, there may be times when we need to let go of our own ideas, and give up our standpoint or processes.

This is when listening as an ally, understanding someone’s view point and recognising their perspective can help to move a situation forward.

Staying open minded and curious can help find a mutually beneficial solution in a collaborative work environment.

title: Reflection point
body:
Think about the your current work situations:

  • What are you working on that you find difficult to ‘let go of’?
  • What is holding you back?
  • Where could letting go be helpful to the overall collaboration?


The following scenarios explore examples of where letting go and leaning into the discomfort helps to find a resolution.

title: Scenario
body: Review the following scenarios and reflect on these situations to find out when letting go and managing your inner thoughts can be beneficial.

_items.body: Nikita is working on a cross organisational project with other environmental professionals but is struggling as they attempt to streamline processes and align environmental policies. The project teams seem unable to agree on a way forward, so progress is slow and frustrating.
Tim explains that the process his organisation uses is necessary for the emissions reporting framework as data needs to be collated and available to the facilities department.
Jack suggests he may have a different process from his organisation, which is a better tool than the one Nikita is using, and could help her and speed up the work.

body:
Which process should they move forward with?

Select the correct answer, then select Submit.

_items.text: Nikita should use the system she is most familiar with which will help achieve the task in hand.
Tim’s process would enable shared visibility and will align with the wider objectives of the emission's reporting framework.

_feedback.correct: That’s right sometimes in collaborative situations people may need to give up their own preferences and or use a less sophisticated system in order for a combined longer-term improvement to be made.

_incorrect.final: That’s not right. sometimes in collaborative situations people may need to give up their own preferences and or use a less sophisticated process in order for a combined longer-term improvement to be made.

_items.body: John arrives to join a new team and prepares to attend his first meeting. John is an effective analyst, although a little introspective and sometimes over analyses his own thoughts, which can result in self-doubt and a reluctance to meet new people or push himself forward.

He has met his new boss and visited her new place of work already. It has everything he needs and he thinks the project lead Vishul is polite and enthusiastic about the project. As John expected, the louder and more vocal members of the team dominated the conversation about the IT system.

John’s inner critic was in over drive with self-doubt. “I’m not good enough for the project - they all think I’m not up to the job, I’m not sure I can add anything to this team”

Vishul noticed that John had not contributed and asked his opinion on the suitability of the IT that was provided.

He was taken by surprise as he was lost in thought and replied, “it seems OK, but let’s wait and see”. As soon as he said it, he reflected that his comments were probably received as being negative which he had not meant to do.

body:
What alternate thoughts could have helped John have a more positive reaction?

Select all options that apply.

_items.text: I will wait to be spoken to until engaging in a conversation.
I am here due to my skills and experience I would add to this bullet point - ‘and I have a valuable contribution to make’
I will reach out and share my ideas and insights with the team.

_feedback.correct: That’s right - if John focused on positively reframing his thoughts and recognised why he had been chosen he would enter the new collaborative environment with a positive mindset and kinder inner dialogue.

_incorrect.final: That’s not right - if John focused on positively reframing his thoughts and recognised why he had been chosen he would enter the new collaborative environment with a positive mindset and kinder inner dialogue.

title: Summary and next steps
body:
This module has focused on mindset, inner dialogue and communication strategies; it has looked at the importance of attitude, clear inclusive communications and skills to develop collaborative behaviours. Write ONE action for each of the topics below – something that you will take away and work on over the next four weeks. Prepare to share these with your manager and a workplace buddy who you trust. Share with them your actions – and ask for feedback when they notice you trying these new behaviours.

Select the arrow to see more information on…

_items.title: Developing a growth mindset
_items.body:
When have you had a fixed mindset?
In what situations have you had a growth mindset?
How does it help you achieve your aims?
Action: What can you do differently to develop a kinder more positive inner dialogue to support a growth mindset?

_items.title: Curiosity
_items.body:
How can you use curious questions in your current work collaborations?
Action: Draft some questions, which you can use and identify a range of situations where you can experiment using them to open up the conversation and enable you to build on the relationship.

_items.title: Clear communications
_items.body:
Are there instances when your messages have not been received as intended? Are you aware of the preferred communication styles of those around you? What could you do to learn more about these?
Action: How and when could you plan to use the ‘faster’ communication approach in order to ensure your message is sent and received in the right way and using the most appropriate style? When you have selected a specific time to try this – ensure you ask for feedback from the receiver.

_items.title: Inclusivity
_items.body:
Considering the wider needs of all colleagues is essential for effective collaboration.
Action: What more could you do to consider the needs of those that you work with? How could you disagree with others but at the same time recognise their opinion and contribution?

_items.title: Letting go
_items.body:
Are there situations where you need to let go of a belief or process in order for the team or collective to move forward? Do you consider the bigger picture? By letting go what could be achieved?
Action: At the next opportunity – try this approach. Note down how it feels – what impact it had – and what the outcomes/results were in adapting your style and letting go. What changed?

_items.title: Next steps
_items.body: There are further resources and activities in Module three to enable and support you in developing your collaboration skills further.

title: Tools and techniques
body: Tools and techniques eLearning

title: Introduction
body: This module will explore a range of tools and techniques to help you to be effective when working collaboratively.

title: Tools and techniques
body:
Working collaboratively can be an energetic positive experience that enables a diverse range of talent and skills to come together and create great results. It can also generate a range of issues such as conflicts in teams, problems that need solving or situations where self-doubt arises. Left unaddressed these things can lead to misunderstanding and confusion. Watch the animation to find out more.

Play the video to see...

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Have you ever worked with another individual or team where you have had conflicting objectives, problems to solve or relationship issues?

Having the tools and techniques to help you navigate the inevitable hurdles of collaborative working, can ensure you manage conflicts and problems when they surface.

Leaving them unaddressed can lead to work and performance issues, misunderstandings and ultimately will impact team goals and morale.

Have you ever needed to reflect back on how a situation unfolded, in order to not experience, the same issue again?

How do you manage or cope when there are power struggles within the team?

What techniques could you use to solve problems and find new ways forward when working on complex issues?

Recognising and surfacing problems or conflicting objectives is important to ensure they don’t derail progress and results.

Knowing what techniques to use will help to avoid the need for escalation - but when that is necessary you need to ensure you know the best process to follow.

title: Summary of tools
body:
The following list contains common scenarios that will occur when working collaboratively. You can click a specific item to access the tips and techniques you need – or alternatively you can work through the module in order and review all the tools on offer.

Click on the relevant images to find out more about the topic.

_graphic.title: Identifying stakeholders
_graphic.body: Do you know who to involve and when? Review the stakeholder mapping grid to help you identify potential allies.

_graphic.title: Managing self doubt
_graphic.body: Having self-doubting moments? Can the OK Corral model help you?

_graphic.title: Inner dialogue
_graphic.body: Is your inner dialogue taking over? How could journaling help you develop reflective practice?

_graphic.title: Power struggles
_graphic.body: Power struggles in the team? Identify your sources of personal influence and areas you can develop.

_graphic.title: Problem Solving
_graphic.body: Need help to solve problems? See how creative thinking techniques could help.

_graphic.title: Different perspectives
_graphic.body: Are you and your colleagues stuck on a particular issue? See how perceptual positioning can help you.

_graphic.title: Managing conflict
_graphic.body: Do you have conflicting issues? See common trigger points and review how negotiation styles can help.

_graphic.title: Navigating road blocks
_graphic.body: Hit a road block? Review common reasons why you may need to escalate.

_graphic.title: Letting Go
_graphic.body: Do people always do what they agree to? Managing priorities can be difficult, could Cartesian questions help you to identify what you could let go of?

title: Managing self doubt
body: The OK Corral model can help you learn how to manage self doubt.
instruction: Select the title to see more information on...

_items.title: I’m not OK – You’re OK
_items.body:
When you think you’re not OK but others are OK, you are putting yourself in an inferior position with respect to others.
If you go into a difficult conversation with this mindset, what’s likely to happen?
You’ll be on the back foot, defensive, unsure of your ground, passive and are likely not to get the outcome you need.

_items.title: I’m OK – You’re not OK
_items.body:
People in this position consider themselves superior in some way to others who are seen as inferior and not OK. Their talk about others will be supercilious, contrasting their own relative perfection with the limitation of others.

This position is a trap into which many managers, parents and others in authority fall – they assume that their given position makes them right and, by implication, others are automatically in the wrong and not OK.

If you go into a difficult conversation with this mindset, what’s likely to happen?

You’ll be ready to attribute blame and do all the talking/telling and not listen. There’s more likely to be an argument and less chance of a constructive conversation.

_items.title: I’m not OK – You’re not OK
_items.body:
This is a relatively rare position, but perhaps occurs where people unsuccessfully try to project their bad objections onto others. As a result, they remain feeling bad while also perceiving others as bad.
This can also occur when two people with a so-called ‘victim’ mind-set come together to talk about a problem.

If you go into a difficult conversation with this mindset, what’s likely to happen?

Not a lot. If they ever have a conversation at all, it’s likely to be a mutual whinge.

_items.title: I’m OK – You’re OK
_items.body:
When you consider yourself OK and also frame others as OK, there is no position for you or others to be inferior or superior.
This is, in many ways, the ideal position. Here, the person is comfortable with other people and with themselves. They are confident, happy and get on with other people even when there are points of disagreement.

If you go into a difficult conversation with this mindset, what’s likely to happen?
In this position, you’re confident of your ground and the outcomes you want, but also prepared to listen to the other person with an open mind and work collaboratively to achieve a mutually beneficial result.

title: Inner critic & journaling
body:
Your inner critic can make or break how your day unfolds. One way to help manage your inner dialogue is to use journaling to help soothe your inner critic.

Journaling can help you develop a balanced relationship with your inner critic over time. By recording your thoughts, you can gain insights into your behaviours and moods and from reviewing your notes, identify the situations when it is most likely to appear.

Some ways to get started are:
  • Write about your life
  • Start with five minutes a day
  • Record the things you appreciate
  • Write about events which upset you
  • Write down questions and concerns
  • Respond in a kind and compassionate way to your questions and concerns

title: Reflection point
body:
How aware are you of your inner critic? Choose a ‘way to get started’ to take steps to identify how your inner critic can affect your day.

Next time you’re facing a challenging circumstance or had a difficult day, try journaling about the situation. Journaling may provide you with insight to the problem, a conclusion to your situation, or an idea of actions you can take to take on your challenge.

title: Power struggles and influence
body:
When having power struggles, being aware of your sources of power and influence can help you work collaboratively and more effectively.

Understanding how you influence through development of your leadership skills can have a positive effect on your colleagues, your team, and your organisation.

Review the 14 tactics below and mark yourself out of ten regarding your ability to deploy each tactic, with 10 meaning a high level of ability to deploy and 1 being a low level of ability to deploy.

Hierarchy
By asserting your organisational grade, rank or position.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Consequence
Explaining the positive or negative effects of taking a course of action.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Reciprocity
Calling in existing favours or promising future favours in return.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Coalition
Teaming up and influencing using force of numbers or referencing the expertise of others.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Logic
Using rationality, common sense or an evidence-based approach.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Mood-managing
Getting someone in the appropriate state of mind.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Integrity based
Calling on values and ethics to make a decision.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Bureaucratic
Using the authority of law, procedure, regulation or common organisational practice.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Reputational
Explaining the positive or negative effect upon image and status.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Intelligence
Using high cognitive abilities: judgement, acumen, insight and comprehension.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Experience
Referring to previous participation, involvement or observation with similar circumstances.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Expertise
Using your particular specialism or status as a subject matter expert.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Emotionalism
Deploying an observable sentiment, feeling, sensation or reaction.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

body:
Friendship
Calling upon an existing positive relationship or camaraderie.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to save your answer.

title: Reflection point
body:
How did you score?

For the areas where you scored lower, what actions can you take to develop your ability in these areas? Who can support you in achieving this?

Share the outcome with your line manager to demonstrate your competency or highlight areas which you intend to develop so that you can seek feedback on how you are doing.

title: Problem solving techniques
body:
There can be many problems to solve when working in collaborative situations and at times it can be difficult to find a way forward.

In these circumstances creative thinking techniques can help develop ideas and find solutions to complex problems.

Review the following approaches and think about situations where you could apply these techniques.

Select the arrow to view more.

_items.body:
Convergent and divergent thinking

Thinking as far and wide outside the box to generate lots of ideas requires divergent thinking.

Sorting through the ideas and organising, grouping thoughts and prioritising what to do next is convergent thinking and can help to find a way forward.

Reverse brainstorming

Reverse brainstorming is similar to Reverse Logic. In this technique, you start with defining the problem, then you start to reverse the issue, and then invite ideas about how to achieve it.
Once you have the ideas, you can reverse them to find solutions, for example:
  • Being rude to customers becomes – providing exceptional customer service
  • Poor hygiene becomes display external hygiene rating
  • One type of coffee becomes a wide range of coffee.
  • Long wait becomes - sufficient well trained staff
  • Too expensive becomes introduce a customer reward scheme


Finally evaluate the solutions and make decisions about the actions to take forward.

Role-play scenarios

Role-playing is a commonly used method for learning. When you act out different situations and scenarios, you can develop new ways of looking at an issue and come up with potential solutions.

You’ll also help team members develop confidence and become more comfortable when dealing with unfamiliar situations since they’ll need to respond quickly and think on their feet.

Role-playing involves two or more members of a group acting out a situation. Examples of scenarios may be dealing with a new client, giving a presentation, interviewing, or resolving conflicts. Essentially, you can role-play any situation that might be difficult and that could be improved with rehearsal.

When people are able to role-play a scenario before encountering the situation in real life, they’ll have some practice developing resolutions quickly on their feet. You can also view the scenario in a different way and come up with unique ways of solving problems.

Creative reframing

Reframing a problem or situation can help you reinterpret it. When you present the issue in a new way, you’ll open up different possibilities for how people react, feel, and examine the situation, which can ultimately lead to new solutions.

Consider alternative meanings, contexts, and perspectives for the situation at hand. Also, think about what the problem can teach you. Once you’ve examined these different angles, you might see the situation in a new light and discover a new approach.

You might ask others to reframe the issue for you as well. This can increase the number of angles from which you’ll be able to consider the problem and potential solutions.

Here are some examples of where reframing may help you to generate creative solutions.
Meaning — what else could this mean?
Context — where else could this be useful?
Learning — what can I learn from this?
Humour — what’s the funny side of this?
Solution — what would I be doing if I’d solved the problem? Can I start doing any of that right now?
Silver lining — what opportunities are lurking inside this problem?
Points of view — how does this look to the other people involved?
Creative heroes — how would one of my creative heroes approach this problem?

title: Reflection point
body:
How could you use creative thinking techniques in your own collaborative work contexts?

Next time you’re facing a creative challenge or are stuck on a problem, try to run through the reframing list and ask yourself the questions. Once you’ve done this a few times, you should get into the habit of asking yourself these questions, and making creative use of reframing.

Is there one technique which suits your situation more than others?

There are also useful resources on websites such as Mind Tools, which you can explore for further ideas.

title: Different perspectives
body:
When working collaboratively, being able to see things from other people’s perspectives is useful for creating empathy, dealing with conflict and achieving successful outcomes.

Putting yourself in the shoes of the other person is a useful approach to consider in order to truly understand their perspective. The perceptual positioning model is about doing exactly that – and experiencing the world from three different perspectives.
instruction: Select the title to see more information on each position.  Have a notebook and pen handy – it may be useful for you to write notes as you look through each of the three positions.

_items.title: First position
_items.body:
The first position is of self-association and of enhanced sensory awareness. It is a powerful positive state where you are wholly in the “here and now” and nowhere else. It is about looking at the world solely through your own eyes and no-one else’s, not affected by their views, biases and opinions.

Reflection activity:
Remember a meeting when you were trying to work with someone which did not go particularly well. Imagine yourself in first position and actually being there. Describe the relationship in one sentence. Ask yourself how you are feeling in the moment and what exactly makes the relationship challenging?

_items.title: Second position
_items.body:
The second position is of disassociation and empathy, stepping out of yourself and seeing the world through the eyes of others and being in touch with their hopes and fears, perceptions and emotions. It explores how they understand their world. It allows you to more precisely describe what they value and what you can do for them.

Reflection activity:
Now in 2nd position Imagine yourself as the other person. What was it like hearing, listening and seeing you? Was there anything that may have caused disagreement, animosity or an unwillingness to work with you? Describe the event from their perspective.

_items.title: Third position
_items.body:
The third position is one of neutrality and objectivity. Being an impartial observer allows you a different kind of insight and to give ‘independent’ advice and feedback to yourself.

Reflection activity:
Now you are a subject matter expert in the 3rd perceptual position who has not met anyone in the meeting and is only there to advise on a particular agenda item. What is their impression about your relationship with the other person? Describe it.

title: Reflection point
body:
What situation could you use this technique in to help see things from a different perspective?

What impact will using this technique make?

Return to the first position and re-imagine the meeting being more successful and write down the outcomes.

title: Conflicting objectives
body:
Where cross organisational collaborative relationships are present, the potential for conflict increases. Such teams may fundamentally disagree on the what, who, where, how, when and the why of a shared project or task.

Conflict trigger points originate from a coming together of the different cultures and practices of each organisation.

Use the below diagram to recognise potential future trigger points.

Select the icons on the image to find out more.
_feedback: Ownership: Who is to blame when it goes wrong, or who claims the plaudits when it goes right?
Resources: Who believes they have the biggest claim to share resources?
Communications: The cultural differences in formal and informal information pathways and standards.
Time: The valuing of people’s time evidenced in presenteeism, work intensity and performance objectives.
Rules: The extent to which rules are present and the extent to which rules are followed.
Personality: The value placed upon amiability, charisma and interpersonal skills.
Status: The level of desire for personal or organisational status.
Skills: The specialisms organisations are known for and claim the ‘high ground’ for.
Expectations: Failing to deliver on shared expectations.
Success: How success is measured and communicated and how success is owned.

title: Reflection point
body:
Can you identify any conflict trigger points, which have cropped up in past collaborative working contexts?

Are there any points that you recognise which align with your own personal / internal agenda?

Is there a collaborative working situation which you can foresee having future conflicting objectives?

If so, what actions could you take to start exploring the issues and either mitigate or resolve them?

title: Conflict resolution
body:
The Thomas-Kilmann Five Conflict resolution style model is a helpful tool which can assist you to the right negotiating strategy in difficult situations.

There are five conflict resolution styles, each encouraging you to take a different tact depending on the stakes, the situation, and other factors. There is no absolute right or wrong resolution style. The situation will dictate which one may make one preferable to another.

You can also take the Thomas-Kilmann online questionnaire on Mind Tools to find out more about your natural style.

Below we will take a quick look at each of these five styles.

Select the icons on the image to find out more.
_feedback:
Competing

This is the “win-lose” approach. You act in a very assertive way to achieve your goals, without seeking to cooperate with the other party, and it may be at the expense of the other party. This approach may be appropriate for emergencies when time is of the essence, or when you need quick, decisive action, and people are aware of and support the approach.

Competing can mean “standing up for your rights,” defending a position which you believe is correct, or simply trying to win.

Collaborating
