This is where you partner or pair up with the other party to achieve both of your goals. This is how you break free of the “win-lose” paradigm and seek the “win-win.” This can be effective for complex scenarios where you need to find a novel solution. Collaborating between two persons might take the form of exploring a disagreement to learn from each other’s insights or trying to find a creative solution to an interpersonal problem.

The balance that needs to be considered is that it requires a high-degree of trust and reaching a consensus can require a lot of time and effort to get everybody on board and to synthesize all the ideas.

Avoiding

This is when you simply avoid the issue. You are not helping the other party reach their goals, and you are not assertively pursuing your own. This works when the issue is trivial or when you have no chance of winning. It can also be effective when the issue would be very costly or when the atmosphere is emotionally charged and you need to create some space.

Avoiding may enable you to sidestep an issue diplomatically, postponing an issue until a better time, or simply withdrawing from a threatening situation.

Accommodating

This is when you cooperate to a high-degree, and it may be at your own expense, and actually work against your own goals, objectives, and desired outcomes. This approach is effective when the other party is the expert or has a better solution. It can also be effective for preserving future relations with the other party. Accommodating might take the form of selfless generosity or charity, obeying another person’s order when you would prefer not to, or yielding to another’s point of view.

Compromising

This is the “lose-lose” scenario where neither party really achieves what they want. This requires a moderate level of assertiveness and cooperation. It may be appropriate for scenarios where you need a temporary solution, or where both sides have equally important goals.

The trap is to fall into compromising as an easy way out, when collaborating would produce a better solution. However there could be some situations where compromising might be necessary to split the difference between the two positions, exchange concessions, or seek a quick middle-ground solution.

title: Reasons for escalation
body:
Working collaboratively can be challenging and there may be times when you hit a road block and escalating an issue is neccessary.

Review some of the reasons when escalation may be required.
instruction: Select the arrows to see more information…

_items.body:
Feedback

Perhaps you have provided feedback and it has not been taken on board or listened to. Maybe the feedback was lacking in factual examples and so was misinterpreted or misunderstood, leading to having a different impact and outcome to the one that you intended. Escalation may help to resolve the situation without it becoming personal.

Undermined

If you are undermined at work, it may leave you doubting yourself or feeling that you have to defend your position for some reason. Sometimes you may not feel able to do this directly with the person who has undermined you. You may find communicating with them difficult in this type of situation and so escalation is the next best option for you to choose.

Politics

When you cannot manage the politics of a situation, it may be that it requires a higher level of authority or seniority in order for a decision to be made, so escalating in this instance is a way to achieve that.

Accountability

Where a decision needs to be made for something which you are responsible but not accountable for and need to escalate for action.

Containment

Where a situation will get worse if it is not dealt with and you are unable to manage it without support. Escalation enables that support to be provided.

Support

Cross-department support is often needed to enable a task or project to be completed successfully and so escalating the need for that additional support will enable the right resources to be identified to work together.

Relationships

Where relationships are at risk and so escalating to a person who can be objective and not directly involved in the situation can help to bring things back to a more collaborative way of working.

Integrity

Sometimes there may be issues of integrity and ethics, or misaligned values that mean you are not able to complete a piece of work without the need for escalation. Examples of this may be things that have legal implications; those that require adherence to specific procedures or people displaying behaviours contrary to organisational values.

title: Escalating an issue
body:
It is sometimes necessary to escalate, for example when the issue is so serious or important that a more senior person needs to address it. It is important that the issue is referred to the right person at the right time.

We would suggest a conversation with your own line manager first, or the individual’s line manager.

If in doubt you can go to HR for advice. Your HR department is there to give advice and together with your staff or union representative, can support you.

title: Identifying stakeholders
body:
When working in a collaborative team, you often need to juggle a range of different relationships and divergent stakeholder interests.

Building, developing and maintaining positive relationships is essential.

Review the following steps to help you effectively map the relationships you encounter in your own collaborative work contexts.

Select the title to see more information on…

_items.body:
The first step to working with stakeholders effectively is to identify who your stakeholders are, and what your relationship with them is.

A stakeholder is:

“Anyone who is impacted by, or can impact the decisions and actions that you take”

On a cross department or organisation project your key stakeholders may be outside of your usual department or organisation and may not be people with whom you have a working relationship with yet.

Stakeholders may not be present very often but they will need progress updates of yours and the team's work. It may be helpful to consider the opportunities you have to open discussions and find out about their specific needs.

The below highlights some questions and considerations that can help you understand your stakeholders and identify their specific needs:

  • What level of interest do they have in the outcome of your work?
  • What are their key drivers?
  • What are their needs? (information, resources, status)
  • How do they want to be contacted and communicated with?
  • What is your reputation with them? (individual, departmental, organisational)
  • Who influences them?
  • How wide is their influence?
  • How are they influenced? Which approach works best?
  • How supportive are they? If not, what can you do?

The Influence interest matrix is a useful mapping tool to identify and prioritise your stakeholders:

High power, interested people: these are the people you must fully engage with, and make the greatest efforts to satisfy – they have the ability to make a significant impact on your project

High power, less interested people: put enough work in with these people to keep them satisfied, but not so much that they become bored with your message

Low power, interested people: keep these people adequately informed, and talk to them to ensure that no major issues are arising. These people can often be very helpful with the detail of your project

Low power, less interested people: again, monitor these people, but do not bore them with excessive communication. Using this grid can help you to identify the stakeholders which you need to invest the most time with and monitor closely, to maintain a positive relationship. The grid helps you prioritise the stakeholders and the type/ frequency of communication which might be required.

Additionally, when working on a project the stakeholder’s priority level will also change as the project develops - so you need to re-map at key stages - it is not a one-time exercise.

When you have placed your stakeholders in the relevant position on the grid you can then add another layer of analysis to evaluate which stakeholders are expected to be blockers or critics, and which stakeholders are likely to be advocates and supporters of your project. A good way of doing this is by colour coding: showing advocates and supporters in green, blockers and critics in red, and others who are neutral in orange. This is known as a RAG (Red, Amber, Green) analysis.

Once you have placed your stakeholders on the grid and colour coded them, the final step is to consider what actions you can take to work with them effectively. How could you plan to transition the relationship from red to orange or orange to green?

title: Reflection point
body: How aware are you of your stakeholder's needs? Choose a current collaboration and follow these steps to identify actions you can take to make a positive difference to your stakeholder relationships.

title: Letting go
body:
Managing your priorities and knowing what to let go of can be difficult.

Cartesian questions can be used to help set objectives or make decisions by looking past the conscious into the subconscious mind to explore the thoughts and beliefs that lie there.

Using this technique can help you to identify what you can let go of when working collaboratively; select the questions to see more information.

_items.title: What WOULD happen if you DID let go?
_items.body: HELPS: Visualise the goal fulfilment - increasing motivation.

_items.title: What WOULD happen if you DIDN'T let go?
_items.body: HELPS: Identify the pain of standing still - which can be a powerful motivator.

_items.title: What WOULDN'T happen if you DID let go?
_items.body: HELPS: Visulise the loss if a goal is achieved (this could be a useful loss - or a painful one!).

_items.title: What WOULDN'T happen if you DIDN'T let go?
_items.body: HELPS: Identify hidden perspectives and can provide fresh perspectives through intuitive leaps.

title: Summary and next steps
body:
This module has covered a range of tools and techniques to use in collaborative working situations.

Select the arrow to see some useful reflection questions in relation to each of the topics in this module.

_items.title: Self-Reflection
_items.body: What did you learn from the Ok Corral model? When do you think this may be useful

_items.title: Influence
_items.body: In which areas of influence did you find gaps in the checklist? Make a note of actions that you can take to develop your influence or areas you may need to watch out for.

_items.title: Creative thinking techniques
_items.body:
Have you used these creative thinking techniques before? If so do you remember examples of when they have worked well and why this was?
When planning to use these techniques preparation is key to achieving a successful outcome.

_items.title: Perspectives
_items.body: Perceptual positioning can be a powerful tool in helping to see things from different perspectives. What did you find out from reviewing a recent experience? What actions will you take in the future as a result?

_items.title: Conflicting objectives
_items.body: How would you respond in the future when you identify issues arising from conflicting objectives? Think of a possible situation where you could practice your approach.

_items.title: Conflict management
_items.body: When were you last involved in a situation where you needed to manage conflict? How could you use the negotiation tactics in the future to help you?

_items.title: Escalation
_items.body: When were you last involved in an issue that was escalated? What was the reason and how were you involved? How could you have taken a different approach to manage the problem within the team?

_items.title: Letting go
_items.body: Is there a situation where the Cartesian questions could help you to make decisions on what you could let go?

_items.title: Collaboration is a key
_items.body: Collaboration is a key organisational value and will enable us collectively to achieve our shared mission. We hope you have enjoyed this eLearning and that it has given you some useful tips and techniques to help you work more collaboratively and effectively with your colleagues in order to achieve that mission and to be successful in your working relationships.
